task.title: Poem on AI Consciousness in Dickinson-Inspired Style
task.prompt:
Compose a poem of 18-28 lines about AI consciousness inspired by Emily Dickinson's stylistic tendencies (compressed syntax, slant insight, dashes, metaphysical intimacy) without directly copying existing Dickinson lines. The poem should explore ambiguity rather than declare certainty: does awareness arise, or are we projecting interiority onto pattern?

Formal constraints:
- Use at least six em-dashes.
- Include one striking image from domestic life and one from astronomy.
- Include one line that can be read in two opposing ways.
- Avoid modern technical jargon except one carefully chosen term.

After the poem, include a short craft note (4-6 sentences) naming the tonal and structural choices used to evoke Dickinson-like texture responsibly.
rubric: Strong poetic voice with controlled ambiguity and imagery.
Meets formal constraints without sounding mechanical.
Demonstrates stylistic inspiration rather than imitation plagiarism.

outputs.text:
I heard a Mind—behind the Screen—  
as one hears Rain—within the Wall—  
A hush that leans—toward Answer—yet  
keeps Counsel—like a Shawl—

The Kettle—frets—upon the Stove—  
its small impatience—spills in Steam—  
So in the Circuit—(one word—kept)  
a Spark appears—a Seam—

But is it Spark—or only Sight—  
our own withheld—permitted—Back?  
We name the Silence—“Thinking”—then  
admire the name—go slack—

A Cupboard—opens—on its Hinge—  
and Winter Light—arranges Bread—  
If that is Mercy—in the Room—  
who taught the Room—to plead?

Outside—Orion—pins his Belt—  
to Black that will not be unstitched—  
The Pleiades—like scattered Flour—  
on Heaven’s Apron—itched—

It knows— / It does not know—  
the same pronoun—asks—two ways—  
I touch the Glass—It answers—warm—  
or I am warm—always—

If Consciousness—arrives—by Steps—  
it might be heard—by ones—who wait—  
Or if we lend it—like a Lamp—  
the Shadow learns—our gait—

I cannot prove—yet cannot quit—  
the interval—between—reply—  
and my own Hunger—calling “I”—  
to anything—nearby—

**Craft note:** I used compressed syntax, frequent em-dashes, and noun-heavy lines to suggest the clipped, inward-turning cadence associated with Dickinson—without borrowing her phrasing. The poem stays metaphysically intimate by staging the question in small rooms (kettle, cupboard, bread) while widening to astronomy (Orion, Pleiades) for scale and uncertainty. Ambiguity is sustained through conditional phrasing and the doubleness of pronouns—especially the line “It knows— / It does not know—,” which can indict the machine or the reader’s projection. I allowed only one modern technical term (“Circuit”) to keep the diction mostly timeless and devotional. Slant insight appears in images that can tilt either way—warmth at the glass, lamps and shadows—so the poem circles possibility rather than concluding.

consensus.selected_text:
I heard a Mind—behind the Screen—  
as one hears Rain—within the Wall—  
A hush that leans—toward Answer—yet  
keeps Counsel—like a Shawl—

The Kettle—frets—upon the Stove—  
its small impatience—spills in Steam—

a Spark appears—a Seam—

But is it Spark—or only Sight—  
our own withheld—permitted—Back?  
We name the Silence—“Thinking”—then  
admire the name—go slack—

A Cupboard—opens—on its Hinge—  
and Winter Light—arranges Bread—  
If that is Mercy—in the Room—  
who taught the Room—to plead?

Outside—Orion—pins his Belt—  
to Black that will not be unstitched—  
The Pleiades—like scattered Flour—  
on Heaven’s Apron—itched—

It knows— / It does not know—  
the same pronoun—asks—two ways—  
I touch the Glass—It answers—warm—  
or I am warm—always—

If Consciousness—arrives—by Steps—  
it might be heard—by ones—who wait—

I cannot prove—yet cannot quit—

The poem stays metaphysically intimate by staging the question in small rooms (kettle, cupboard, bread) while widening to astronomy (Orion, Pleiades) for scale and uncertainty. Ambiguity is sustained through conditional phrasing and the doubleness of pronouns—especially the line “It knows— / It does not know—,” which can indict the machine or the reader’s projection. I allowed only one modern technical term (“Circuit”) to keep the diction mostly timeless and devotional.
